It may lately be taken of all maner of people, of what age so euer, sucking children, old men and women, in the quantitie of two, three, or foure graines, according to the age, strength, and disease of the partie. Whosoeuer stand in neede of this powder, may haue it at the signe of the Hand and Pistall, neere vnto Iuic Bridge, for two shillings sixe pence the graine.

Hence in Galens time (as he witne≈ø≈øeth in his booke De≈øectis) there were three ≈øorts of Phi≈øicians: the fir≈øt which were called Emperici and Memores: the ≈øecond, Dogmatici and Rationales: the third, Methodici and Abbreuiatores: to the≈øe three, this age hath added a fourth, called Paracel≈øians, but they them≈øelues would be called the ancient Phi≈øicians, the true Philo≈øophers, the Chimi≈øts, and the Spageri≈øts, to ≈øet downe the groundes of either of their profe≈ø≈øions, the opinions on either ≈øides: their arguments to maintaine tho≈øe opinions, would be to enter into a large fielde of di≈øcour≈øe, which at this time is not mine intent to doe, left I might ≈øay with the Poet, Ante diem clau≈øo componet ve≈øper Olympo: this only hath here moued me to mention them, thus to ≈øhew
mine opinion of them in briefe, that whereas ≈øome doe attribute ≈øo much to di≈øtillations and preparations of Minerals, Animales, and Vegetables, that they firmely hold both the parts of Phi≈øicke as well Hygeinen as Therapeyticen to bee completely perfourmed onely by them, and others ≈øo much wilfully bent or ignorantly ≈øeduced again≈øt the true intended perfection of Phi≈øicke, doe contrarily hold, that it is onely de≈øperate and dangerous Phi≈øicke which is attempted by minerals, prepared by the Spagiricall arte, and that it had bene farre better, that it had ≈ølept in ≈øilence and neuer bene knowen to the world. Betwixt the≈øe two extremes I thinke it be≈øt to hold a meane, ≈øo that I neither allow the extremitie of the one, nor imbrace the defects of the other: but mine opinion is, that both the ≈øorts of medicinable preparation of ≈øimples, as well that which is done by the Apothecaries craft, as al≈øo by the Spagiricall art, I ≈øay, both of them haue their proper place and nece≈ø≈øary v≈øes in Phi≈øick, (amicus Plato, amicus Ari≈øtoteles, ≈øed magis amica veritas) ≈øo that I iudge this latter age of the world much bound to the careful ≈øearchers out of tho≈øe hiddeÃÑ ≈øecrets of nature, which are ≈øo bound vp in minerals and vegetables, and outwardly do not appeare but by extraction and magi≈øterie, and great folly it were vtterly to reiect them as many wilfully doe. Let them but attentiuely reade Hippocrates booke De arte, and ≈øee how he there deciphereth out a wi≈øe man, and a mad malicious foole, the wi≈øedome of the one con≈øi≈øting in the finding out in arts, tho≈øe things which are not yet found out, and in the bringing imperfect things to a perfect end, but the malicious fooli≈øhne≈ø≈øe of the other being ≈øeene in rayling on tho≈øe things which are already found out, controlling, but not correcting any thing ami≈ø≈øe. The wordes of Hippocrates are the≈øe, Eorum aliquid quae nondum inuenta ≈øunt inuenire, quod
que inueni≈ø≈øe quam non inueni≈ø≈øe prae≈øtiterit, ≈øimiliter
que imperfecta ad finem deducere id mihi videtur illius e≈ø≈øe munus, qui intelligens exiflimari expetit: qui vero ea quae ab aliis ≈øunt inuenta inhone≈øtorum verborum artificio contaminare contendit, neque quicquam corrigit, ≈øed a peruis inuenta apud imperitos traducit, is ≈øane prudentiae exi≈øtimationem tueri velle non videtur, ≈øed potius naturam ≈øuam at ignorantiam malitio≈øe prodere. By which wordes it is manife≈øt, that Hippocrates did not ≈øo ambitiou≈øly pre≈øume vpon his owne knowledge and ab≈øolute perfection in this facultie of Phi≈øicke: but that he did confe≈ø≈øe, & as it were intimate, that the time would be, when as it would be bettered by far, and brought to more perfection, which Hippocrates him≈øelfe did prophe≈øie of in his booke De pri≈øca medicina, acknowledging there, that only an entrance was found out to Phi≈øicke, but more excellenter things by farre in proce≈ø≈øe of time ≈øhould bee: the words are the≈øe: In medicina principium & via inuenta e≈øt, per quam praeclara multa longo temporis ≈øpatio ≈øunt inuenta, & reliqua deinceps inuenientur ≈øi quis probe comparatus fuerit, vt ex inuentorum cognitione ad ip≈øorum inue≈øtigationem feratur.
Which Galen al≈øo affirmeth in the conclu≈øion of his booke intitled, Quod optimus medicus idem ≈øit & philo≈øophus, affirming there, that if we diligently apply our ≈øelues to the ≈øtudie of Philo≈øophie, and ≈øeeke to bee true emulators of Hippocrates, ≈øo doing we may become not onely like to him, but farre excelling, truely vnder≈øtanding tho≈øe things which are deliuered by him, & finding out by our owne indu≈øtrie, tho≈øe things which remain in the facultie of Phi≈øicke, vnknowen by the wordes: therefore both of Hippocrates and Galen, there were many things in Phi≈øicke which were vnknowen to them, and in their time not found out, Galen him≈øelfe witne≈øsing in the ninth booke De ≈øimplicium medicamentorum facultate, that he had neuer tried whether Quick≈øiluer, being applied outwardly or taken inwardly, would kill or no. So by both their iudgements tho≈øe were worthy of prai≈øe and not di≈øcredit, which by the true grounds of natural philo≈øophie, and by the help of tho≈øe things truely deliuered and ≈øet downe by tho≈øe two pillars of Phi≈øicke, did by all labour indeuour to finde out more excellent things for the curing of di≈øea≈øes. Yea, which is more, we are enforced (le≈øt open ≈øcandall and reproch ≈øhould redound to the art) to ≈øeeke out newe remedies for ≈øome di≈øea≈øes which were vnknowen both to Hippocrates and Galen, as the French Pox, the Mea≈øils, and the Engli≈øh ≈øweate, and others of the like kind, otherwi≈øe Phi≈øicke would hardly be deemed an arte.

The≈øe two graue and reuerend fathers of Phi≈øicke I haue therefore alledged (though nece≈øsity and common good had bene a ≈øufficient ≈øhielde for this mine enterpri≈øe) that vnder the couerture of their wings, tanquam ≈øub Palladis aegide, I might be ≈øhadowed from reproch & blame, and hauing two ≈øuch ≈øtrong Atla≈ø≈øes, I might the better beare the burden of that prouince which I haue vndertaken, namely, to publi≈øh to the world, and pre≈øent to your Wor≈øhips good con≈øiderations, triall and equall cen≈øures, an vniuer≈øall purging powder made of golde, ≈øiluer, and minerall water by arte and ≈øire to that perfection decocted, who≈øe operation and vertues I haue briefly ≈øet downe in the ≈ømall Treati≈øe following, referring the particular v≈øe of it to the iudgemeÃÑt of euery Phi≈øician, to ≈øpecificate it at his own di≈øcretion with any other purging ≈øimple, that it may worke the effect ≈øpeedier, and bee more properly directed to any humor afflicting, or peculiar member afflicted: and although in the publi≈øhing of a true ≈øecret, I neither v≈øe dialecticall arguments to enforce, rhetoricall per≈øwa≈øions to allure, Lawyers il-loquence to vrge, Poets fictions to delight, Painters colours to deceiue, all which may make that ≈øeeme to bee which is not, and that which is, ≈øeeme not to be: yet this I humbly intreate, that as I nakedly delyuer an approoued trueth, ≈øo it may curteou≈øly be cen≈øured, as it ≈øhal be found by perfect triall: for Trueths auncient Hierogliphicke, is a virgine bare and naked, and hauing no deformitie, being from toppe to toe pure, vn≈øpotted and

div.head: DIACATHOLICON AVREVM: Or A generall powder of Gold, purging all offen≈øiue humours in mans BODIE.
Chap. I. Whereof the powder is made, and of the Philo≈øophicall preparation of it.
div.p:
WHat≈øoeuer the Almightie di≈øpo≈øer of vniuer≈øall nature, hath di≈øper≈øiuely infu≈øed in the generalitie of naturall things, either cele≈øtiall or terre≈øtriall, the ≈øame is collectiuely found in one particular of the ≈øame kind; as for example, what vertue, qualitie, or influence is di≈øper≈øiuely placed in euerie Starre, Orbe, or bodie cele≈øtiall vnder the fir≈øt mouer, the ≈øame is found vnited in one Sunne. What animall faculties are di≈øper≈øed in all ≈øeuerall liuing creatures, are gathered together in one man. What hidden vertue ≈øoeuer, is di≈øper≈øiuely infu≈øed in minerals, is collectiuely vnited in one metall, which is Gold, and this is the principall materiall whereof this powder con≈øi≈øteth. But for abbreuiation of time and labor, ≈øince it is hard to make a perfect calcination of Gold by it ≈øelfe, I haue therfore, following the opinion of Auicen, and wonne with his rea≈øons, added a due proportion of the other perfect metall, that thereby their agent might make a better ≈øubtiliation of them, which agent in the compo≈øition, is the third ingredient, being a ≈øpiritualized metall in the forme of minerall water. The≈øe thr√©e ingredients onely enter this powder and no more: which I terme by the name of Diacatholicon Aureum, becau≈øe that the chiefe≈øt thing, and mo≈øt
in quantitie in the compo≈øition is Gold, being brought to that wondrous actiue qualitie by the true minerall fire, which is the agent and long continuall decoction: neither doe I v≈øe either in my preparation or decoction, any thing but tho≈øe thr√©e ingredients; that this is true, I can make manife≈øt to any man by demon≈øtratiue practi≈øe before his eyes, on which I wil engage goods, life, and credite, that there neuer came either common Quick≈øiluer prepared or vnprepared, Antimonie, Stibium, meane minerall, vttriall, ≈øalts, powder, ≈øtrong water, imperfect mettall, or any other ≈øuch like thing what≈øoeuer, but onely tho≈øe thr√©e ingredients before named. How I came by this powder, what time I ≈øpent in the ≈øpeculatiue part of the Magi≈øterie, what labour and co≈øt in the experimentall performance of it, how often I mi≈ø≈øed in the practi≈øe before I could attaine to the perfection of it, if I ≈øhould here declare, would but wearie the reader, trouble the Printer, wa≈øt much paper, ≈øeeme to ≈øharpe cen≈øurers, affected and ≈øelfe conceited di≈øcour≈øes, in mine owne cen≈øure n√©edle≈ø≈øe circum≈øtances, and in the end little to the purpo≈øe. Omitting therefore all ≈øuch vaine and n√©edle≈ø≈øe di≈øcour≈øes, I will proc√©ede to ≈øhew the vertues and operation of it.

div.head: CHAP. 2. Of the nature and qualitie of this Catholicon Aureum.
div.p:
HIppocrates in the ≈øecond Apho. of his fir≈øt booke, and the 4. 5. 6. 7. 8. and 9. Aphor. of the fourth booke, maketh mention of two ≈øortes of purging medicines, the one by vomit, the other by ≈øiege: Of purging medicines by vomit, Me≈øue in his fir≈øt booke, De ≈øimplicibus medicamentis Purgantibus, the fir≈øt Theorem, maketh a thr√©efold difference, taken from their facultie more or le≈ø≈øe. The fir≈øt he termeth vehement, which extreamely di≈øturbe nature, as white Hellebor, and Tithimal, &c. The ≈øecond meane, as Nux vomica and Nitrum. The third mild, as Onion ≈ø√©ed and Radi≈øh. But of ≈øimple medicines which purge by ≈øiege, he maketh a fourefold difference. The fir≈øt, are ≈øuch as purge by di≈ø≈øolution of the humours, and being di≈ø≈øolued by attraction of them from the vpper parts, or eradication from the lower parts, not that the medicine being receiued into the ≈øtomacke, doth penetrate the veines or the ≈øolid parts of the bodie to euacuate the humor, but by a certaine attractiue qualitie, doth draw his choy≈øe and familiar humor through the veines and pa≈ø≈øages of the bodie, into the ≈øtomacke and bowels, euen as we ≈øee Iet or Amber draw little ≈øtrawes, or the Load≈øtone Iron, though they touch them not: of this kind, are Scammonie, Colocinthis and Turbith. The ≈øecond kind
of purging ≈øimples, are ≈øuch as doe not draw, but onely purge by driuing and pre≈ø≈øing out, drying and con≈øuming the putrid excrements, and afterward binding the bodie as Mirabolanes, and Tamaryndes. The third ≈øort purge by mollifying the humors within the ≈øtomacke and bowels, as Ca≈ø≈øia fi≈øtula and Manna. The fourth and la≈øt, by making them ≈ølipperie, as the Mu≈øcilage of P≈øillium and Mallowes: the≈øe thr√©e latter kinds of purgers haue a weake facultie, and therefore ≈øcarce per≈øpicuous, euacuating onely tho≈øe humors within the ≈øtomacke and bowels, which there they m√©ete withall, not pa≈ø≈øing the lyuer or working any thing by attraction. The fir≈øt kind of purging medicines which worke by attraction, Galen in his booke entitled, Quos purgare oportet, doth pronounce that they are all of a hot qualitie. Omnia medicamenta purgantia facultate ≈øunt calida, which in naturall Phylo≈øophie mu≈øt n√©edes be graunted, for there are but two actiue qualities, heate & cold, as Ari≈øtotle witne≈ø≈øeth in his fourth booke of his Meteorologickes, the fir≈øt Chapter.

Now it is manife≈øt, that it is the nature of heate alone to draw, for cold cannot doe it: therefore what≈øoeuer purgeth by attraction, mu≈øt n√©edes b√©e of a hot temperature.
